It is my understand<wbr></wbr>ing that the nearest comparison to game theory behaviour that has been demonstrat<wbr></wbr>ed is the behaviour of stock market traders, which is renowned as an unreal environmen<wbr></wbr>t quite unlike the real world and a game that few people can play well (because they can\'t sufficient<wbr></wbr>ly divorce themselves from reality when large amounts of real money is involved.)\n" });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888668-858', { "TS": 1271888668, "Text": "Nearly everything that is left off of a harvested plant is used for either protection from land erosion or for scrap feed for animals. Surely it can not be called waste, therefore it should not be used as a biofuel. I don\'t see the need for change, although I understand Petroleum isn\'t going to be around forever. I see that scientists these days are focusing more on the second generation bio fuels of \"Grassolin<wbr></wbr>e\" which is the break down of cellulose, but if we are going to be using all most of the cellulose on the production of \"Grassolin<wbr></wbr>e\", where is the ceelulose available for our ruminant animals? The ones that provide us with the crucial proteins required in our everyday eating? Ruminants break down ceelulose and produce red meat, that contains our required proteins. I think a lot a thought needs to be put in such an experiment<wbr></wbr>, before all action is taken place." });

Whilst this idea has superficia<wbr></wbr>l appeal, anyone with a modicum of common sense (one doesn\'t even need to be an epidemiolo<wbr></wbr>gist) would realise that if the birth rate in a country exceeds the death rate, the population will grow in size, regardless of what caused the deaths. \r\nThis distractio<wbr></wbr>n about overall population growth represents a particular logical fallacy (a strawman) which I know has been burnt to the ground countless times by your critics. Yet you still keep rre-erecti<wbr></wbr>ng it as \"proof\". It clearly is proof of nothing. JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888670-298', { "TS": 1271888670, "Text": "I\'m always surprised how \'unscienti<wbr></wbr>fic\' the analysis of race/gende<wbr></wbr>r issues is in science.  For instance, the statement \n\"significa<wbr></wbr>nt numbers of women and underrepre<wbr></wbr>sented minority chemists and chemical engineers say they were discourage<wbr></wbr>d from pursuing\"\nis purely anecdotal.  How do we know that white male chemists and chemical engineers were not similarly discourage<wbr></wbr>d?\nThe implicit assumption of most of these studies seems to be that there must be some form of discrimina<wbr></wbr>tion, as \'proven\' by the numerical discrepanc<wbr></wbr>ies.  This is the worst kind of scientific bias.  I\'d have more respect for these kinds of studies if they included other possible explanatio<wbr></wbr>ns.\n  I also object to the idea that strict numerical parity should be our goal.  There is not a single male teacher at my children\'s elementary school, yet they are not burdened with task forces, review committees and hiring inquisitio<wbr></wbr>ns trying to establish gender parity.  When will we grow up enough as a society to accept that peoples choices come primarily from their cultural and personal preference<wbr></wbr>s, not from biases in \'the establishm<wbr></wbr>ent\', even if the results do not reflect our intellectu<wbr></wbr>al preconcept<wbr></wbr>ions." });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888677-992', { "TS": 1271888678, "Text": "This is an incredibly misleading article, and would people stop using the word infinite to describe the gravity in a black hole? There is a limit (or there is with our science us little fallible beings created) It\'s just that the escape velocity exceeds that of the (known) fastest thing in the universe, which is light. And simply because the spaceship appears to stop doesn\'t mean that it did, in reality. Science is based off of observatio<wbr></wbr>ns, so it is true that the spaceship stops to an observer outside of the black holes point of no return, but what about the observers inside of the point of no return? They would still be there, and not stuck in one frame of time (or a quantum second, If remember correctly)<wbr></wbr>, so what does this say? Well, it is called the point of no return, which means that once you pass that invisible line the escape velocity of the black hole is too great to be overcome by anything (we think!) in the universe, so you cannot go back, essentiall<wbr></wbr>y splitting the two observers into places where they can never compare their data, this solves the paradox of appearing to stop, he does stop, yet he doesn\'t. I\'d like to hear you\'re comments on this, I probably overlooked something!" });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888683-648', { "TS": 1271888683, "Text": " The analogy that time \'stops\' at the edge of a \'point of no return\' just seems silly.  What can you expect from such a young species in a universe said to be billions of years old?  Just take a look at all the holes in table of elements.  One should note that \"reality\" concerning the universe as a whole has changed repeatedly since the invention of the telescope.  The old theory of the ball in a spaceship argues that things may move faster than light, provided some sort of device is used to prevent passengers from becoming smudges on the back wall at velocity speeds.  Now I\'m just a bit irritated about this whole mess.  First, a small group of folk decide for the rest of us that Pluto is no longer a planet.  Now, black holes don\'t exist?  Those were a few of my favorite things to read about as a child.  What next, maybe that galaxies are not really collection<wbr></wbr>s of stars, but rather rips in space-time looking through a skewed light field at our own juxtaposit<wbr></wbr>ion in space?  Or perhaps that we are simply billions of tiny motes lost in our understand<wbr></wbr>ing of our own ineptitude when it comes to observatio<wbr></wbr>n of our surroundin<wbr></wbr>gs.  It\'s the flat earth theory all over again.  Our understand<wbr></wbr>ing of the universe is like a candle to the sun, we have a long way to go before we get there.  Someone develop the warp engine already, then we can zip out there and take a look." });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2007/06/21-01.html
id: jsid-1271888683-648  (jsk), 41803238 (dsq) 	parent: jsid-1271888677-992 (jsk) 
name: Dave 	email: leocreon@yahoo.com

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888685-311', { "TS": 1271888685, "Text": "In aerobic municipal biological waste treatment, air is pumped into wastewater to provide oxygen that encourages massive bacteria growth. The bacteria \"eat\" the waste, breaking it down until there is much less biological oxygen demand (BOD) and the hazard to the environmen<wbr></wbr>t is controlled<wbr></wbr>. A secondary effect is that carbon dioxide in the air dissolves into the water making carbonic acid that acidifies the water enough so that it has to be neutralize<wbr></wbr>d. I\'m concerned that tiny bubbles would 1) prevent light from reaching life in the sea 2) would exacerbate ocean acidifying & hurting coral 3) encourage unnatural bacteria or algae blooms 4) use energy that makes the problem worse" });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888689-786', { "TS": 1271888689, "Text": "I think your reasoning is flawed. Yes natural events can have the same effects, but the total magnitude of the effect is what needs to change for it to mater. Bubbles may be produced naturally but since their natural creation is balanced by their destructio<wbr></wbr>n the total amount of bubbles in the seas and hence the total heat they reflect does not change. We can shift the equilibriu<wbr></wbr>m in one direction or another. This can in turn change the balance between heat radiated into space and heat received from the sun. As long as the total concentrat<wbr></wbr>ion of a greenhouse gas changes it does not matter what the source is. The effect will be the same." });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888704-427', { "TS": 1271888705, "Text": "Micro-bubb<wbr></wbr>les have the potential to: \nRadically disrupt feeding and survival strategies\nDisrupt foodwebs\nChange nutrient availabili<wbr></wbr>ty\nAlter habitats, physically and chemically\nAffect the weather and change weather patterns\nAlter ocean stratifica<wbr></wbr>tion\nAlter and interfere with ecosystem function\n...\n\nBy changing the oceans\' albedo -  using micro-bubb<wbr></wbr>les of air:  changing the amount of heating; changing the amount of light that penetrates (reducing the growth of phytoplank<wbr></wbr>ton - positively correlated with light, temperatur<wbr></wbr>e and nutrient availabili<wbr></wbr>ty); altering the habitat and dynamics of the basis of the ocean foodweb - phytoplank<wbr></wbr>ton & zooplankto<wbr></wbr>n; changing the stratifica<wbr></wbr>tion of areas of the ocean;  possibly altering circulatio<wbr></wbr>n patterns; changing the weather patterns, potentiall<wbr></wbr>y disrupting the mechanisms that bring nutrients from the ocean bottom to the surface, increasing available Oxygen at the surface, and changing nutrient availabili<wbr></wbr>ty; changing ocean chemistry.<wbr></wbr>..\n\nIf much more light is reflected, the ocean will be darker & cooler, marine flora and fauna  which have evolved to live within certain parameters will be affected as their habitat rapidly changes. Creatures which have adapted using properties of light to create camouflage<wbr></wbr>, or assist in hunting or evasion strategies will be negatively affected. All the seabirds which feed by spotting fish may find hunting difficult. \n\nWhile the micro-bubb<wbr></wbr>le idea is certainly creative, and might well cool the planet, be easy to turn off, and relatively cheap and easy to produce. I think it has huge potential to cause absolute havoc in ocean ecosystems - (which we still don\'t have a decent working model for - or even a reasonable approximat<wbr></wbr>ion).  At a time when we are just beginning to investigat<wbr></wbr>e the possibilit<wbr></wbr>y that our long-found<wbr></wbr>ed beliefs are wrong - \"that the ocean is so vast and so productive<wbr></wbr>, and phytoplank<wbr></wbr>ton being the basis of productivi<wbr></wbr>ty, there is no possibilit<wbr></wbr>y that we could seriously damage ocean productivi<wbr></wbr>ty by long term exploitati<wbr></wbr>on and removal of productive<wbr></wbr>ly useful biomass...<wbr></wbr>\"\nHowever, research is starting to appear which suggests that over-explo<wbr></wbr>itation may indeed lead to an impoverish<wbr></wbr>ed, nutrient poor system, affecting species which are not exploited.\n\nWhen we are still stumbling around in the dark, knowing so little of how the ocean really functions - to implement this sort of idea is criminally irresponsi<wbr></wbr>ble. There is literally NO way to determine what the impacts will be on ocean eco-system<wbr></wbr>s, because we can\'t model it in any meaningful way. \n\nOk, so we could turn it off - if/when we realize there\'s a problem. How much more damage can our oceans take and still provide a significan<wbr></wbr>t fraction of the world\'s food supply?\n" });

overer+of+the+AIDS+drug+Lamivudine+%28a+nucleoside+analogue%29+that+WHO+recommends+in+combination+with+other+toxic+drugs+as+the+first-line+antiviral+therapy+treatment+regimen+in+Zimbabwe+and+other+developing+nations%2C+has+a+potential+conflict+of+interest.%0D%0A%09Elsevier+appeared+to+react+merely+from+fear+of+losing+profits%2C+instigated+by+political+blackmail%2C+not+from+any+regard+for+a+fit+process+of+science.++Subsequently+it+convened+an+anonymous+panel+to+obtain+the+changes+the+blackmailers+wanted%2C+although+the+panel+of+5+reviewers+could+not+conclude+that+either+of+the+two+articles+on+trial+were+a+%E2%80%9Cthreat+to+global+public+health%E2%80%9D+or+were+%E2%80%9Cpotentially+libelous%E2%80%9D+%28the+originally+stated+concerns+by+Elsevier%29.++Meanwhile+no+one+on+the+panel%2C+not+to+mention+the+blackmailers%2C+seems+to+be+aware+that+the+idealistic+reputation+of+peer+review+has+been+effectively+challenged%2C+if+not+damaged%2C+in+recent+years.++Richard+Smith+the+editor+of+the+British+Medical+Journal%2C+for+example%2C+noted+in+2002+that+%E2%80%9CRefereeing+is+expensive%2C+time-consuming%2C+inaccurate%2C+subject+to+bias+or+worse%2C+doesn%E2%80%99t+catch+errors+let+alone+fraud--and+there%E2%80%99s+no+objective+evidence+that+it+works+better+than+the+independent+judgment+of+a+qualified+editor%E2%80%9D.+++Indeed+hundreds+of+studies+have+endeavored+to+evaluate+the+effectiveness+of+peer+review%2C+with+no+definitive+evidence+found+that+it+protects+integrity%2C+or+that+it+reliably+results+in+better+papers+being+published+%28The+Great+Betrayal%2C+Horace+Freeland+Judson%3A2004%29.++Indicative+is+a+review+of+135+comparative+studies+by+Jefferson+et+al+%28JAMA+287%2C+5+June%3A+2784-86%29%2C+presented+at+the+Fourth+International+Congress+on+Peer+Review+in+2002+that+concluded%3A+%E2%80%9CUntil+such+research+is+undertaken%2C+peer+review+should+be+regarded+as+an+untested+process+with+uncertain+outcomes%E2%80%9D%21%0D%0A&js-CmtEmail=sss.professor%40yahoo.com
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888706-503', { "TS": 1271888706, "Text": "             It’s a misleading insinuatio<wbr></wbr>n that a journal has a peer review problem because they accepted a paper rejected by another journal, since this occurs on a regular basis in publishing<wbr></wbr>.  Additional<wbr></wbr>ly, Medical Hypotheses had previously published other articles that questioned the HIV-AIDS hypothesis<wbr></wbr>.  Furthermor<wbr></wbr>e, many of the complainer<wbr></wbr>s of Medical Hypotheses had also petitioned the Library of Medicine to deselect Medical Hypothesis abstracts in MEDLINE/PU<wbr></wbr>BMED because Medical Hypotheses was not peer reviewed, but the petition was rejected reinforcin<wbr></wbr>g their complaint as spurious.  Finally, instead of complainin<wbr></wbr>g about the journal, the main complainer<wbr></wbr>s being ‘scientist<wbr></wbr>s’ could have readily published an article as a rejoinder to Duesberg et al to point out any specific “errors or misinterpr<wbr></wbr>etations” themselves<wbr></wbr>, rather than waiting for an anonymous panel 8 months later to do it.  Ignoring all these basic facts, Elsevier then turned a blind eye to what in all appearance<wbr></wbr>s seems to be the central purpose of the paper that Duesberg et al responded to (Chigweder<wbr></wbr>e, 2008), which was to avenue the eliminatio<wbr></wbr>n of those who criticize the HIV-AIDS hypotheses through the conception of a computer model based upon the very assumption<wbr></wbr>s questioned by critics; a model that generated an estimated number of 330,000 unnecessar<wbr></wbr>y AIDS deaths in South Africa, almost 25 times greater than the number of AIDS deaths indicated by the South African Statistics agency.  The paper then implied that government run public health agencies are ‘science authority’<wbr></wbr>, that scientists that disagree or criticize official pronouncem<wbr></wbr>ents of public health agencies should be punished legally while the lead author Pride Chigwedere<wbr></wbr>, as the co-discove<wbr></wbr>rer of the AIDS drug Lamivudine (a nucleoside analogue) that WHO recommends in combinatio<wbr></wbr>n with other toxic drugs as the first-line antiviral therapy treatment regimen in Zimbabwe and other developing nations, has a potential conflict of interest.\r\n\tElsevier appeared to react merely from fear of losing profits, instigated by political blackmail, not from any regard for a fit process of science.  Subsequent<wbr></wbr>ly it convened an anonymous panel to obtain the changes the blackmaile<wbr></wbr>rs wanted, although the panel of 5 reviewers could not conclude that either of the two articles on trial were a “threat to global public health” or were “potential<wbr></wbr>ly libelous” (the originally stated concerns by Elsevier).  Meanwhile no one on the panel, not to mention the blackmaile<wbr></wbr>rs, seems to be aware that the idealistic reputation of peer review has been effectivel<wbr></wbr>y challenged<wbr></wbr>, if not damaged, in recent years.  Richard Smith the editor of the British Medical Journal, for example, noted in 2002 that “Refereein<wbr></wbr>g is expensive, time-consu<wbr></wbr>ming, inaccurate<wbr></wbr>, subject to bias or worse, doesn’t catch errors let alone fraud--and there’s no objective evidence that it works better than the independen<wbr></wbr>t judgment of a qualified editor”.   Indeed hundreds of studies have endeavored to evaluate the effectiven<wbr></wbr>ess of peer review, with no definitive evidence found that it protects integrity, or that it reliably results in better papers being published (The Great Betrayal, Horace Freeland Judson:200<wbr></wbr>4).  Indicative is a review of 135 comparativ<wbr></wbr>e studies by Jefferson et al (JAMA 287, 5 June: 2784-86), presented at the Fourth Internatio<wbr></wbr>nal Congress on Peer Review in 2002 that concluded: “Until such research is undertaken<wbr></wbr>, peer review should be regarded as an untested process with uncertain outcomes”!\r\n" });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/03/elsevier-to-editor-change-contro.html

Posting comment 146
Request sent: http://js-kit.com/comment.put?tid=jst-1&js-CmtName=Roberto+Ligrone&ref=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.sciencemag.org%2Fsciencenow%2F2010%2F01%2F15-02.html&js-CmtText=The+research+clearly+deals+with+fresh-water+fish.+In+marine+fish+the+major+problem+is+excess+water+entering+the+body+through+the+gills.+The+fact+that+in+the+larvae+of+rainbow+trout+ion+uptake+by+the+gills+initially+prevails+on+oxigen+uptake+does+not+surprise+me%3A+arguably+the+need+for+a+specialized+respiratory+organ+decreases+with+animal+sizes%2C+whereas+ion+balance+becomes+particularly+critical+%28especially+in+fresh+water%29.+The+gills+of+fish+are+a+modification+of+the+pharingeal+basket+of+tunicates%2C+an+organ+specialized+in+filtration+%28for+feeding+in+marine+habitats%29.+Overall%2C+I+can%27t+see+the+importance+of+the+results.&js-CmtEmail=roberto.ligrone%40unina2.it
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888731-769', { "TS": 1271888731, "Text": "The research clearly deals with fresh-wate<wbr></wbr>r fish. In marine fish the major problem is excess water entering the body through the gills. The fact that in the larvae of rainbow trout ion uptake by the gills initially prevails on oxigen uptake does not surprise me: arguably the need for a specialize<wbr></wbr>d respirator<wbr></wbr>y organ decreases with animal sizes, whereas ion balance becomes particular<wbr></wbr>ly critical (especiall<wbr></wbr>y in fresh water). The gills of fish are a modificati<wbr></wbr>on of the pharingeal basket of tunicates, an organ specialize<wbr></wbr>d in filtration (for feeding in marine habitats). Overall, I can\'t see the importance of the results." });

Request sent: http://js-kit.com/comment.put?js-CmtName=JV&js-CmtParentID=jsid-1271888659-767&js-CmtEmail=joel.voss%40gmail.com&tid=jst-1&ref=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.sciencemag.org%2Fsciencenow%2F2010%2F03%2Fscienceshot-translating-a-dogs-g.html&js-CmtText=Good+question+-+dogs+do+not+distinguish+words+in+human+language+per+se.+They+are+reinforced+%28via+some+form+of+reward+or+punishment%29+to+associate+a+particular+sound+with+a+particular+effect+%28i.e.%2C+%22bad%22+%3D+about+to+be+hit+with+newspaper%2C+%22good%22+%3D+treat+coming+my+way%29.+The+word+itself+has+no+inherent+meaning+to+the+dog%2C+as+you+could+just+as+easily+train+it+to+associate+%22bad%22+with+a+reward+and+%22good%22+with+a+punishment.+It+is+quite+a+different+story+if+a+dog+can+actually+produce+different+sounds+to+convey+different+messages+to+another+member+of+their+species.+Of+course%2C+this+ability+might+have+been+learned+by+the+dog+at+some+point+in+the+same+way+as+they+%22learned%22+the+meaning+of+%22bad%22%2C+but+the+fact+that+they+actually+produce+the+sound%2C+rather+than+merely+respond+to+it%2C+is+what+is+important+here.
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888744-534', { "TS": 1271888744, "Text": "Good question - dogs do not distinguis<wbr></wbr>h words in human language per se. They are reinforced (via some form of reward or punishment<wbr></wbr>) to associate a particular sound with a particular effect (i.e., \"bad\" = about to be hit with newspaper, \"good\" = treat coming my way). The word itself has no inherent meaning to the dog, as you could just as easily train it to associate \"bad\" with a reward and \"good\" with a punishment<wbr></wbr>. It is quite a different story if a dog can actually produce different sounds to convey different messages to another member of their species. Of course, this ability might have been learned by the dog at some point in the same way as they \"learned\" the meaning of \"bad\", but the fact that they actually produce the sound, rather than merely respond to it, is what is important here." });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2010/03/scienceshot-translating-a-dogs-g.html
id: jsid-1271888744-534  (jsk), 42136598 (dsq) 	parent: jsid-1271888659-767 (jsk) 
name: JV 	email: joel.voss@gmail.com

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888749-773', { "TS": 1271888750, "Text": "The 1988 exchange was only a fledgling first round debate and Science canceled the other rounds after Blattner, Gallo, and Temin lost round 1 so decisively<wbr></wbr>.  Their primary evidence was epidemiolo<wbr></wbr>gical correlatio<wbr></wbr>ns instead of microbiolo<wbr></wbr>gical, and since correlatio<wbr></wbr>ns cannot imply causation, and strong microbiolo<wbr></wbr>gical evidence must be available against HIV prior to it\'s inclusion in the 1985 AIDS definition<wbr></wbr>, the definition<wbr></wbr>\'s required match between the hypothetic<wbr></wbr>al cause HIV and AIDS were artifactua<wbr></wbr>ly generating most of the correlatio<wbr></wbr>ns, so argumenjts of B, G, T looked very weak.  The reason that so much dissent or rethinking exists is because there has still not been a review of the literature that presents strong microbiolo<wbr></wbr>gical evidence against HIV, for example.  So whether it\'s 1988, 1998 or 2010, debate is still justified until that vital evidence is produced because the Emperor still is without clothes.  Also, without that evidence, using the term denialist \'begs the question\' in circular fashion because the very premise that justifies the term (strong evidence exists against HIV) is merely assumed while the term is used to avoid presenting evidence to verify the premise.  So the claim that many people are dead because of AIDS denialism is an additional dimension of begging the question, because again, the evidence that HIV causes AIDS must be produced to make the claim. That\'s what this is all about. Chigwedere et al also beg the question with their computer model, that\'s set up on the very assumption<wbr></wbr>s in question, then the flawed model produces numbers that are being used to reinforce the concept \'denialism<wbr></wbr>\'  and justify imprisonme<wbr></wbr>nt of those who dissent...<wbr></wbr>another tautology.  US National Library of Medicine rejected the petition by the \'complaini<wbr></wbr>ng 18\' to delist Medical Hypotheses because their argument about peer review was spurious.  The phrase you use, \"fanatical zeal to support authority even when that authority exists to extinguish a people\", could just as easily be applied to the AIDS establishm<wbr></wbr>ent if AIDS drugs are really hurting patients instead of helping, which is a point that dissenters make, and therefore crucial to discuss until those that work for the AIDS establishm<wbr></wbr>ent can adequately resolve data descrepanc<wbr></wbr>ies that indicate the drugs harm more than help long term.  Elsevier as owner of course has the right to do what it wants with MH, but it brings into question whether owners of journals should be held to a higher criteria than merely looking at the bottom line, because the history of science strongly suggests that because peer review has many flaws, which include it being used by those of the dominant view, including by knowledge monopolies and research cartels, to hold on to the primary funding sources and hence power.   The fears are understand<wbr></wbr>able, especially as fanned by those in the AIDS establishm<wbr></wbr>ent, but this is supposed to be the process of science, not a religion although the \'complaini<wbr></wbr>ng 18\' seem to be doing there best to force conversion and baptism. " });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888752-48', { "TS": 1271888752, "Text": "One problem that I see here working with people with Asperger\'s is that, judging from my own and others experience<wbr></wbr>s, people tend to assume that we can\'t understand people\'s motives, when the truth of the matter is that we typically can easily envision a multitude of reasons why a person would act in certain ways, we also recognize that nonverbal communicat<wbr></wbr>ion is hopelessly inaccurate<wbr></wbr>, and so, rather than just prescribe a motive based on multiple plausible possibilit<wbr></wbr>ies with little reason to pick one over another, we say I don\'t know, which is the only factual response one can really make.\nI am constantly amazed that with the huge literature on common, everyday mistakes on verbal and nonverbal communicat<wbr></wbr>ion, so many people still claim to understand what the people around them are supposedly communicat<wbr></wbr>ing. If people stopped assuming they understood and spent more time asking for clarificat<wbr></wbr>ion, the world would be a better place.  \nI applaud the research and am interested in what they find in future research, I just hope the researcher<wbr></wbr>s don\'t let preconcept<wbr></wbr>ions and assumption<wbr></wbr>s about what Aspies or any other group are actually thinking color their interpreta<wbr></wbr>tions." });

By doing this, much sun-light can reflect into the sky, so my method can efficientl<wbr></wbr>y cool the earth.\r\n\r\nThen I have another opinion that we can mosaic zillions of micro-refl<wbr></wbr>ective-mate<wbr></wbr>rial on the roads, streets, motorways or on the many roofs of buildings. JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888769-304', { "TS": 1271888769, "Text": "The theory pertaining to the energy of the expanding universe falling below the energy threshold required for creating matter, just moments after the big bang, seems to be linked to these new finding.  How can time stop in a black hole from the gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal pull in one spot inversely exceeding the speed of light due to the theory of relativity<wbr></wbr>?  At the very beginings of our universe\'s creation, there was not only all the mass of a previous star condensed into a small space; rather, the entire mass of the entire universe was compacted into a relatively even smaller space in terms of the densities required to contain the matter.  From these assumption<wbr></wbr>s about time slowing to zero once past a certain event horizon, one could conclude that the big bang never made it off the starting block.  the minute all matter in the known universe was created, it simultaneo<wbr></wbr>usly stopped time itself by acting as a \"Black Hole\" and has just sat there ever since.  the phenomena that resulted did no such thing.  if light is unable to escape the grasp of a black hole, representi<wbr></wbr>ng only a tiny fraction of the original mass concentrat<wbr></wbr>ion during the big bang, it leads to only one conclusion<wbr></wbr>.  there is something out there faster than the speed of light. How else would light, energy, mass, and time be able to grow outward through such a brilliantl<wbr></wbr>y enormous in strength concentrat<wbr></wbr>ion of matter? The inverse of this would be rather than something exceeding the speed of light during the big bang, gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal pull in a black hole does not overcome time, but rather bends it away from the standard observatio<wbr></wbr>n point. using infinite terms in describing black holes is a mathematic<wbr></wbr>al mis-interp<wbr></wbr>retation of a number that is larger than we can easily comprehend<wbr></wbr>.  clearly, if the gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal pull inside a black hole cannt be larger than the initial value of gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal pull at the first instants of the big bang, the value of gravity in the black hole cannot be infinite by means of being trumped by the big bang concentrat<wbr></wbr>ion of mass.  mathematic<wbr></wbr>s is what can no longer describe our universe in quantitati<wbr></wbr>ve terms that are accurately applicable to real world physics. You\'d be hard-press<wbr></wbr>ed to find that single bubble with a microscope<wbr></wbr>, let alone noticing the difference with the naked eye, so don\'t be thrown by the misleading<wbr></wbr>, frothy, ocean surface photos accompanyi<wbr></wbr>ng the article.  Spread those bubbles over a unit thickness area of one square meter and 99.9999% of the sunlight will miss those 1 ppm bubbles.\r\n\r\nAlso note, the bubbles are micro-bubb<wbr></wbr>les (specifica<wbr></wbr>lly ~ 2 microns according to Seitz) that could stay suspended for days because of their size (remember Stokes Law). This process is low cost compared to upending the entire world economy (which will work only if EVERY country goes along with it), completely reversible in a matter of days, and is based on solid scientific concepts. With a nod to William of Ockham, sometimes the simplest solution is the best.  " });

If you believe the ice caps won\'t melt and drown us all, fine. But to say that as humans we have NEGLIGIBLE effect on our environmen<wbr></wbr>t is, pardon my french, c’est vraiment des conneries!" });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888850-21', { "TS": 1271888850, "Text": "100% wind power is possible, but there are a couple of details to consider.  First, the fact that wind power can be produced continuous<wbr></wbr>ly doesn\'t mean it can be produced in volumes and at times that are consistent with customer demand.  For that you need storage, which is very expensive.  Second, wind machines produce DC power that has to be passed through an inverter, and that process creates some technical problems that could affect the large existing stock of AC motors.  Third, you\'d need a lot of wind turbines.  Finding an acceptable place (or places) to put them might be problemati<wbr></wbr>c along the eastern seaboard.  Wind power could also be produced in the midwest and moved to the east coast, but that requires transmissi<wbr></wbr>on lines that are equally difficult to site.\n\nBottom line:  like anything else, 100% wind power is possible, but it will be expensive, time-consu<wbr></wbr>ming and require lots of infrastruc<wbr></wbr>ture most folks do not want in their back yards." });

The authors of thei withdrawn article are absolutely free to say whatever they want.  They just can\'t say it in a \"medical\" or \"science\" journal, because it\'s not science, it\'s a political editorial.  \n\nA publicatio<wbr></wbr>n calling itself a \"medical\" or \"science\" journal has a reputation to protect, and it can only do so by limiting its content to articles backed up by data and accepted research protocols. Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888870-448', { "TS": 1271888870, "Text": "\"As Einstein demonstrat<wbr></wbr>ed in his Theory of General Relativity<wbr></wbr>, a passenger inside a spaceship traveling toward a black hole would feel the ship accelerati<wbr></wbr>ng, while an outside observer would see the ship slow down\"\r\n\r\nThis is incorrect. The passenger would be in free fall, so wouldn\'t feel any accelerati<wbr></wbr>on - in fact would feel no different to empty space until tidal forces became significan<wbr></wbr>t at a few thousand km distance (for a stellar mass black hole), and that would feel altogether different from an accelerati<wbr></wbr>on.\r\n\r\nObserver outside wouldn\'t see the ship slow down, they\'d see it accelerate into what would seem like an infinite distance into the black hole, getting progressiv<wbr></wbr>ely more red-shifte<wbr></wbr>d. If the observer could view events on the ship, or the ship\'s clock, THAT would appear to slow down.\r\n\r\nAnd this is a prediction from Einstein\'s theory - I don\'t think he actually \'demonstra<wbr></wbr>ted\' it. He didn\'t put a passenger in a ship and send it into a black hole. That wouldn\'t be ethical. :)\r\n\r\nMatter does take an infinite time to reach the horizon of the existing hole, from the point of view of anyone outside, but it very quickly enters the horizon of the NEW hole ( = old hole + spaceship ), and at that point there\'s no problem in saying that it becomes part of the hole from the point of view of an external observer. Perhaps there are Planck length ambiguitie<wbr></wbr>s here, but I doubt our friends in Ohio have any more idea about that than you or I.\r\n\r\nI wish science journalist<wbr></wbr>s would be honest and state that some scientists have developed a mathematic<wbr></wbr>al methodolog<wbr></wbr>y or model in which black holes cannot form - which is interestin<wbr></wbr>g enough - instead of suggesting they\'ve \"shown\" anything to be the case. These models inevitably have their own assumption<wbr></wbr>s and provisos which may or may not be far-fetche<wbr></wbr>d. It\'s not as if these guys are overturnin<wbr></wbr>g the standard view of black holes at all." });

2C+and+has+yet+to+be+seen.&js-CmtEmail=posterlogo%40yahoo.com
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888898-520', { "TS": 1271888898, "Text": "Folks - be careful with reading too much into this. It is certainly a great discovery that multicellu<wbr></wbr>lar organisms are now known which can be anaerobic (this was already known for many unicellula<wbr></wbr>r organisms) - especially since the vastly efficient energy harvesting that comes from being aerobic was thought to give rise to complex multicellu<wbr></wbr>lar life in the first place. So the lifeform gets its energy through other processes, not by respiring oxygen (O2). However - and this is the biggie - it does NOT mean we have knowledge of ANY life that can live without atomic Oxygen (O). Think about it - this anaerobe, all previously known anaerobes, and every other lifeform currently known needs the same basic elements: C H N O P S, because these are critical for the building blocks of life (nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, carbohydra<wbr></wbr>tes). This \"new\" lifeform still uses all those same building blocks and its fundamenta<wbr></wbr>l chemistry is still exactly the same as every other life form. In this short, this is definitely still exactly \"life as we know it\". It would be very misleading to think this, or any other anaerobe, \"lives without oxygen\". Anyway, that wouldn\'t be a problem on other planets... there is enough molecular oxygen to go around the universe, so this should in no way fuel speculatio<wbr></wbr>ns about outer space life. Again, it\'s the \"structure<wbr></wbr>\" of life that is unique on Earth, and all know life, including this new one, follows the same basic structure. If were to find something, for example, that used Silicon instead of Carbon or Sulfur in place of Oxygen, or informatio<wbr></wbr>n storage in something other thand DNA/RNA, or \"proteins\" made out of something other than amino acids, etc... THAT would be something fundamenta<wbr></wbr>lly very different, and has yet to be seen." });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2010/04/scienceshot-animals-that-live-wi.html
id: jsid-1271888898-520  (jsk), 43818869 (dsq) 
name: Sam 	email: posterlogo@yahoo.com

It needs to, because in order to grow and survive, it needs more oxygen than other cells.\n\nSo, what if... we could use some intravenou<wbr></wbr>s anaerobic food and quite literally remove all the oxygen a patient breathes, and replace it with nitrogen? Would the cancer die, while the other cells remained alive on their alternate fuel supply?\n\nTo some extent we already do this in short bursts. Sprinters store anaerobic fuel. That means its possible.\nThe only real problem is preventing kidney or liver failure during a forced anaerobic coma." });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888909-967', { "TS": 1271888909, "Text": "Funny. But what if we simplify matters and studies this from a more scientific perspectiv<wbr></wbr>e and say that the person with and without prostheses weigth the same and that we know that the only thing generating force in this case are the thighs (the person with prostheses have no calf muscles and can therefore not run as fast as the healthy person). They both are as equally strong but one thing differs the knee joints. It\'s logical that the spring joint bounces better than the biological joint which mean that more of the force added per step remains longer in the spring. The conclution is that the prosthese person use his energy more efficiant than the biological one. To greatly simplify this think about this as two balls, the balls weigths the same (does not matter in vacuum but anyways) but the other ball is more springy ( the prosthese)<wbr></wbr>. If dropped from the same higth which of them stops bouncing first? The ball which\'s not as springy as the other ball ofcourse! The springier the ball is, the more of its momentum is konserved which leads to lesser force during the impact with the ground which is energy consuming when running. \n\nThe prosthese is not as fast as the biological and therefore should they be accepted in shorter laps where the momentum konsevatio<wbr></wbr>n doesn\'t give any advantage, like 100meters sprint. But longer laps give prostheses unfair advantages<wbr></wbr>. " });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271888987-972', { "TS": 1271888988, "Text": "As DrugMonkey notes, the scientists who are actually doing the work know there\'s not currently any way around animal experiment<wbr></wbr>s for many types of research.  For example, I needed to study the interactio<wbr></wbr>n between cells in the bone marrow and a bone tumor.  Because I didn\'t want to hassle of dealing with animals and also because research review boards require it, I looked long and hard for an alternativ<wbr></wbr>e way to study the phenomenon<wbr></wbr>, but eventually got as far as I could with culture models.  I wrote up my attempts to find an alternativ<wbr></wbr>e way of doing the research in my report to the review board.  There\'s simply no way to model a bone marrow environmen<wbr></wbr>t in a tumor bearing animal in a culture dish, and then to examine the effect of a drug requires different routes of administra<wbr></wbr>tion, none of which can be done in vitro.\n\nBelieve me, I wouldn\'t have done the animal research if there was any way I could have gotten around it, and pretty much everyone else felt the same way. It\'s costly, time consuming, and inconvenie<wbr></wbr>nt, but I was able to do research that uncovered a new treatment path for an incurable cancer. Was that a justifiabl<wbr></wbr>e reason?  " });

At the center of spiral galaxies is the bulge which contains the majority of the mass of the galaxy. These stars have random orbits around the spherical bulge. The rest of the galaxy, known as the disk, rotates around the  bulge. Learn some science before you spew b.s." });

Posting comment 530
Request sent: http://js-kit.com/comment.put?js-CmtName=Arthur+Appelgren&js-CmtParentID=jsid-1271889007-325&js-CmtEmail=aappelgren%40nicehomesamerica.com&tid=jst-1&ref=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.sciencemag.org%2Fscienceinsider%2F2010%2F04%2Fevolution-big-bang-polls-omitted.html&js-CmtText=All+theories+to+be+theories+have+to+be+able+to+be+wrong.+It+is+called+falsifiability.+It+does+not+matter+whether+it+could+be+wrong+or+not%2C+it+just+matters+that+it+is+a+valid+scientific+theory+and+it+counts+as+both+valid+and+important+in+understanding+basic+science.+Newton%27s+theories+are+both+valid+and+wrong+at+the+same+time.+They+have+been+supplanted+and+expanded+by+Einstein+and+others+since.+Even+if+Darwinian+Evolution+is+wrong%2C+or+rather+incomplete+in+that+it+does+not+adequately+explain+things+and+in+the+future+a+new+theory+is+formulated+that+does+a+better+job%2C+it+does+not+matter+because+that+is+the+future+and+today+Darwinian+evolution+by+process+of+natural+selection+is+the+current+foundational+model+for+all+of+the+biological+sciences.+As+such+it+is+an+extremely+important+bit+of+knowledge+to+have.+Maybe+if+the+people+that+disagreed+with+the+theory+so+much+actually+took+the+time+to+learn+about+it+they+might+come+up+with+something+better+than+saying+%22God+did+it%22.+But+that+would+take+scientific+literacy.
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889034-388', { "TS": 1271889034, "Text": "All theories to be theories have to be able to be wrong. It is called falsifiabi<wbr></wbr>lity. It does not matter whether it could be wrong or not, it just matters that it is a valid scientific theory and it counts as both valid and important in understand<wbr></wbr>ing basic science. Newton\'s theories are both valid and wrong at the same time. They have been supplanted and expanded by Einstein and others since. Even if Darwinian Evolution is wrong, or rather incomplete in that it does not adequately explain things and in the future a new theory is formulated that does a better job, it does not matter because that is the future and today Darwinian evolution by process of natural selection is the current foundation<wbr></wbr>al model for all of the biological sciences. As such it is an extremely important bit of knowledge to have. Maybe if the people that disagreed with the theory so much actually took the time to learn about it they might come up with something better than saying \"God did it\". But that would take scientific literacy." });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/04/evolution-big-bang-polls-omitted.html

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889034-656', { "TS": 1271889034, "Text": "Everyone needs to stop throwing around the term \"infinite\"<wbr></wbr>.  There can be no infinity.  Infinity ruins all physics.  A black hole is not a point in space where gravity grows infinitely strong, it\'s not infinitely massive, nor infinitely small.  It\'s strength of pull on another object is based on both their masses and the distance between them.  What happens if one is floating in space and they are drawn by earth gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal pull.  They fall toward earth at 9.8m/s2, accelerati<wbr></wbr>ng until reaching terminal velocity.  Same thing would happen in a black hole.  You\'d just fall to the core of it\'s gravity and probably be liquified by the intense heat of friction.  Riddle me this, based on the equation for gravity that gives us 9.8m/s2 here on earth, could there be a black hole with a mass producing a force of gravity of 299,792,45<wbr></wbr>8m/s2, the speed of light? Technicall<wbr></wbr>y, with enough mass and using that equation, yes.  What if it were more than the speed of light?  One law of physics against the other." });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889040-292', { "TS": 1271889040, "Text": "Nobody\'s saying the Milky Way is a black hole. There\'s just a fairly large black hole at the centre. And yes, it\'s expected that every galaxy should have one at the centre (in addition to having a few million normal-siz<wbr></wbr>ed black holes scattered among its stars).\n\nThe other thing about black holes is that all they lead to is obliterati<wbr></wbr>on. Even before you arrive at the centre of the black hole, all the particles of your body are stripped apart and completely causally separated. (Causally separated means placed completely and forever out of reach of any possible contact or effect on each other - as if every particle is in a different universe..<wbr></wbr>. but they\'re not.) That\'s something for anyone with pretty ideas about fractal universes to think about." });

These require \"tweeks\" in the theory, much as relativity modified the original laws of motion as stated by Newtonian theory.  In mathemtics<wbr></wbr>, the rules are created and the individual cases of mathematic<wbr></wbr>al epxression<wbr></wbr>s are based on the rules. Forinstanc<wbr></wbr>e, there is more than one system of mathematic<wbr></wbr>s (particula<wbr></wbr>rly self consistant systems of geometry, although Euclidian is the only form with which most of us are familar). Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889058-484', { "TS": 1271889058, "Text": "I second this. The general formula of popular science journalism seems to be: Find something that could suggest something earth-shat<wbr></wbr>tering; Find some other scientist with half a brain (a whole is too much, none is too little) and ask them what they think; report as if both ideas have even-level credibilit<wbr></wbr>y.\n\nNew math that works pops up all the time, it doesn\'t mean it is so. When it comes to theoretica<wbr></wbr>l physics, which is any kind of physics we can\'t directly observe, it is all about what theory makes the most accurate prediction<wbr></wbr>s with the least complexity<wbr></wbr>. In that order.\n\nA complex theory that makes even the smallest improvemen<wbr></wbr>t to prediction<wbr></wbr>s is the new working model. One that can be made more simple but retain the same level of predictive quality, is the new working model.\n\nThe reason that we think of time as fluid is that we are, ourselves, observers. And the math must take that into account and the easiest way to do that is to assume time is fluid. This doesn\'t mean it is. It just means that the math is more simple if it is. Since it makes the same quality prediction<wbr></wbr>s as the HORRIFICAL<wbr></wbr>LY complex alternativ<wbr></wbr>e theories you need to make time progressio<wbr></wbr>n constant, it is the preferred working model.\n\nIt isn\'t perfect. For example, the 3 body problem. But it does a better job of predicting things like the orbit of Mercury and how much light will bend around the sun than did the model before it.\n\nSo, what about this new idea with black holes makes better prediction<wbr></wbr>s? Well, assuming all else is even, it fits with how we have always presumed the universe to work. Which is that informatio<wbr></wbr>n, and I mean here the physics concept of informatio<wbr></wbr>n, can\'t be destroyed. Because if you could make informatio<wbr></wbr>n vanish, our history would vanish. We would not be able to trust any observatio<wbr></wbr>ns, nor even our memories. Black holes have long been thought to break this flow of informatio<wbr></wbr>n. There are a few ways to sort of avoid it, such as Hawking\'s idea that black holes infuse other universes with that informatio<wbr></wbr>n, and I guess presumably it could one day enter another black hole and re-enter ours? Not sure how that works. There is also the idea that when a black hole would evaporate the caught informatio<wbr></wbr>n would be released. However, if this theory suggests another way to have all the effects of a black hole without the loss of informatio<wbr></wbr>n, then perhaps it is a better model.\n\nWe wouldn\'t know until we could make observatio<wbr></wbr>ns of it. Actually, we may never know, because if black holes make informatio<wbr></wbr>n vanish, we can\'t really trust what we think we know about them, even when observed." });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2007/06/21-01.html
id: jsid-1271889058-484  (jsk), 44051096 (dsq) 	parent: jsid-1271888870-448 (jsk) 
name: DampeS8N 	email: dampee@earthlink.net

There is one thing insofar that does escape a black hole and that is tachyons.  The only way something solid could travel through a black hole would be to travel faster than light.  Traveling faster than light would obliterate anything solid due to the sheer gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal friction, and that\'s not counting the gravity of a black hole.  To send something solid to FTL flight would require something that can make a static warp bubble or a self contained bubble of gravity.  Gravity that is strong enough to withstand outside gravity.  Something like that doesn\'t exist with current technology<wbr></wbr>.  Yet.  But if Tachyons can escape a black hole, then other things can as well.  When looked at through a spectrosco<wbr></wbr>pe, a black hole can be seen spewing out cosmic energy from the top and bottom.  That is what is left afterwards<wbr></wbr>, and is the building blocks of all matter/ene<wbr></wbr>rgy in the universe.  Look up both black holes and white holes and you will see they correllate<wbr></wbr>.  They are what constantly pulls in and expells the energy that creates the universe, a literal cosmic sized recycling center that keeps the universe balanced.  Without a balancing factor, the universe would not be here for it would destroy itself." });

That understand<wbr></wbr>ing may lead to acceptance if we BELIEVE it is sound, but understand<wbr></wbr>ing is only a logical process - logical processes are faulty when false axioms are assumed (something humans appear highly prone to do).  Acceptance of any matter is by no means necessary to be literate on that matter.\n\nIn fact, science as we know has been driven by paradigm shifts - by people who do not accept the common beliefs. Accepting something just because it APPEARS logically sound would be practicall<wbr></wbr>y suicidal to the scientific community.  It\'s only when we accept theories HYPOTHETIC<wbr></wbr>ALLY that there\'s enough context surroundin<wbr></wbr>g them to truly develop them into what may one day be the whole truth." });

Certainly, all the informatio<wbr></wbr>n and scientific studies point to toxin(s) as the major cause of AD and mercury is the likely culprit.  Mercury is highly neurotoxic<wbr></wbr>. Mercury is in all probabilit<wbr></wbr>y the major factor, but certainly not the only factor, in causing  many neurologic<wbr></wbr>al disorders and in particular Alzheimer\'<wbr></wbr>s. Not to be afraid of what he has given us. \n\nThe evidence we see ( and God has given us the power to see this) is that he got us here through evolution. This reminds me that years ago many christians believed the world was flat and that the sun could not have sun spots. Realizing the earth is not flat, and realizing the sun has spots, has not meant christiani<wbr></wbr>ty is doomed. It has meant that the universe God dealt us is more wondrous and amazing than we could imagine, if not for science. \n\nHow on earth did faith ever get so caught up trying to deny science. It is not healthy. Would God want good Christians to deny what science has let us see and let us use? I don\'t think so. \n\n\n" });

Posted in http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/04/talking-evolution-gets-bible-sch.html

Tiny black holes can emit thermal radiation, but the microwave background means this can never lead to a net emission for any black hole more than a tenth of a millimetre across.\n\nAnd white holes... haven\'t a clue what you\'re on about. What goes in, stays in. If you throw a billion tons into a black hole, you get a black hole that\'s a billion tons heavier, and it doesn\'t come out again. The universe is timeless, which means that it was never created, and it will never end because it was started; it was just in existence. Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889306-75', { "TS": 1271889306, "Text": "Lee Smolin first put forward this idea many years ago, and excellentl<wbr></wbr>y expanded upon by Quentin Smith, called \"fecund universe\" theory. The idea is that a star in another \"parent\" universe collapsed and created a black hole, where our universe exists around the edge of the disk of the infinitely spiralling and expanding black hole\'s singularit<wbr></wbr>y point. Many black hole\'s in our universe would potentiall<wbr></wbr>y have other \"baby\" universe\'s at their singularit<wbr></wbr>y points, and so on. It would be evolution on the grandest of scales, as universes seed themselves with stars with the ability to propagate more universe\'s<wbr></wbr>, constantly refining themselves toward the right state of elements and conditions for this to occur. This theory is more appealing to me than our universe\'s existence inside of a wormhole." });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889318-819', { "TS": 1271889318, "Text": "How do we explain dreams--wh<wbr></wbr>en we dreamed that something happened and within a few days, weeks, months, or years, that incident does occur in real life? Most of us call that supernatur<wbr></wbr>al or a phenomenon<wbr></wbr>. Most explain that it is a time warp. Why can\'t it be a new dimension? Why does it have to be a malfunctio<wbr></wbr>n of time? Why does the word \"time\" have to be mentioned at all. There has always been many collisions throughout the infinite existence of space. Asteroids and planetary bodies collide all the time, not only once! So, as far as my understand<wbr></wbr>ing of the universe, there is no single \"big bang\" that caused our existence. If we want to mention big bangs, we should include the other big bangs that continue to happen in space, even as we speak, and those that have occurred long ago. We should consider the other big bangs or planetary collision that have occurred before the so-called ultimate big bang that scientist have theorized. There is also an infinite number of universes out there in space. And they were not created either; they were just there. We do not have the capacity to comprehend the dimension that could be used to accurately describe their existence. So, we should indeed leave it that. We will never know or understand everything<wbr></wbr>, we can only do our best to understand our world. In fact, we have done pretty well with our limited resources of science and mathematic<wbr></wbr>s." });

I\'m not saying this is common, but neverthele<wbr></wbr>ss I see no reason why a person couldn\'t be a proponent of Creation, and yet have formal mastery of the principles of Evolution. Such a person would have the ability to use scientific knowledge to draw evidence based conclusion<wbr></wbr>s about Evolution, and yet for whatever reason may decide to make decisions about the natural world based on Creation.\n\nOr using your question of gravity as an example:\n\n\"Gravity is the result of the warping of space-time by mass where bodies follow the shortest path as dictated by this curvature.<wbr></wbr>\" What about \"gravity is a force mediated by a massless (and hypothetic<wbr></wbr>al!) elementary particle with spin-2?\"  Does your question about relativity require me to categorica<wbr></wbr>lly denounce the existence of a graviton? JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889347-256', { "TS": 1271889347, "Text": "I believe we are building the house much bigger than it needs to be. Dark energy is an aspect of space/time with  0 energy. How? IT is not an energy.  It\'s an aspect. Now you will have to redo your math. Now, dark matter,on the other hand, for it to exist, it would have to have some kind of buoyancy pressure to keep it from collecting in massive solids. Since the earth still weights the same, dark energy has not collapsed. Now, if buoyant (as many believe and HST has taken pictures of  vast hydrogen clouds connecting galaxies \"proving\" dark matter) it just would not work. Imagine you tunneling through earth. the deeper you go, the lighter you get. That is because the deeper you go, you have more earth all around you instead of under you. This action could not keep a galaxy together. I Believe dark matter can be explained away with 3 points. (1)...the mass of super massive black holes have been seriously under estimated. The observed rotation curve at the outer edge of the galaxy can be explained by a \"beefed up\" super massive black hole.  The center rotation curve can also be explained as space/time is being dragged around. That is,from our vantage point,we see stars near the center going slower than they are from there own vantage point thus matching the rotational curve of the outer rim. This time dilation makes it difficult to weight mass especially if you omit it. (2)...Ever<wbr></wbr>y globular cluster has an intermedia<wbr></wbr>te mass black hole. Also, stellar mass black holes are probably more common than thought, Our galaxy is at least 8 billion yrs old, A lot of star evolution for massive stars, think about it. If a stellar mass black was not \"feeding\" or part of a binary system, it would go undetected<wbr></wbr>. Now in (2) we have most but not all of the mass we need. (1) we have a little relativity and extra mass, now (3) Gravity propagates at the speed of light. If the sun would disappear altogether<wbr></wbr>, it would take about 8 min.before we see it disappear and at the same moment earth would stray from it\'s orbit. Now, with that in mind, consider a star say 30,000 Lt yrs away in the arm preceding the sun around the galaxy. The sun is now  feeling the gravity of that star at a point where it was 30,000 yrs ago.The star is not there now. It has moved farther around the galaxy during that time with a weaker pull of gravity following the inverse square law.  In other words, each star in an arm of a galaxy feels a \"phantom\" pull of the preceding star more than giving the preceding star a gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal drag. This effect is small but should not be omitted. Pennies makes dollars. Now, why do we need worm holes to explain dark energy and dark matter? Calculus can not tell you what happens inside a black hole or a worm hole (or if it exist) because it is based on theory. Respectful<wbr></wbr>ly, I think we should consider what went over our heads first before adding more rooms to the house than we need. By the way, If the Higgs Boson is discovered<wbr></wbr>, it might be found to give mass to quarks via gravatons which might be indistingu<wbr></wbr>ishable from the strong nuclear force at higher energies.\nI am not a scientist,<wbr></wbr>but this makes since to me. It proposes to explain the origin of the universe by positing a preexistin<wbr></wbr>g \"singulari<wbr></wbr>ty\", itself a prepostero<wbr></wbr>us notion. Surely, you have to ask where did this supposed singularit<wbr></wbr>y come from. In fact, if you keep asking where did that come from, you eventually arrive at an act of creation by something that always existed. Call it what you want, eventually all those cryptic mathematic<wbr></wbr>al notations come to naught. Also, as I understand the concept of the \"scientifi<wbr></wbr>c method\" the \"Big Bang Theory\" should be called the \"Big Band Hypothesis<wbr></wbr>\" because there is no way to test it empiricall<wbr></wbr>y with some human devised experiment<wbr></wbr>. Same goes for the \"Theory of Evolution\" which should be called \"Darwin\'s Hypothesis<wbr></wbr>\" or something similar. No one has yet devised an experiment to test any of it\'s tenets that has ever yielded fruitage. Everything observed in nature is really only evidence that most , if not all, species have within them the ability to adapt to new circumstan<wbr></wbr>ces which may result in them looking a little different." });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889418-994', { "TS": 1271889419, "Text": "Astrophysi<wbr></wbr>cists  must eventually come to terms with the fact that the Big Bang does not make sense.  Really now, there was a singularit<wbr></wbr>y, meaning what, a one of a kind thing? and then suddenly it just exploded?  what caused it to explode? was pressure building up inside it? does that mean there was a time before the big bang, during which pressure built up? And to say our universe comes from another universe, well, that\'s something of a cop out, because isn\'t the universe supposed to encompass everything<wbr></wbr>?\r\nNow, you don\'t have to let go of it yet, because evidently the Big Bang theory still has plenty of legs on it.  It\'s the most comprehens<wbr></wbr>ive  (though far from complete) explanatio<wbr></wbr>n they\'ve come up with so far (oh excuse me except for the explanatio<wbr></wbr>n involving the giant bearded man in the white robe who lives in the sky and declared everything into existence) and is stimulatin<wbr></wbr>g additional thinking.  But eventually you\'ll have to move on.  We need a better explanatio<wbr></wbr>n.  It\'s probably obvious that I am not a profession<wbr></wbr>al scientist, but here\'s what I think:  the Big Bang is like the concept of a Point in geometry.  It doesn\'t really exist, but by postulatin<wbr></wbr>g that it does exist, we\'ve come up with a lot of useful ideas that help to explain and measure reality.  So keep at it, but don\'t get to enamored of it, because eventually that theory is going down!" });

Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889458-399', { "TS": 1271889458, "Text": "Actually I do not think either of those fields represent experiment<wbr></wbr>s that establish that life evolved from lifelessne<wbr></wbr>ss which is the basic tenet of evolution. When you take existing life and manipulate it to create a copy or a hybrid all you are establishi<wbr></wbr>ng is that that existing life-forms can be modified by external stimuli. Not too different from what can be done accidental<wbr></wbr>ly with various mutagenic chemicals. You can call it what you want, but I call it adaptation<wbr></wbr>. A simple example can be seen in the faces of abalone divers. Due to the constant exposure to cold water, their body responds by adding a lot of blood vessels especially in the epidermis giving them a very ruddy complexion<wbr></wbr>. Repeated long enough , the offspring of these hardy individual<wbr></wbr>s would likely be born that way. Voila! a new sub-specie<wbr></wbr>s. Still the ability to add blood vessels in response to repeated exposure to cold water was intrinsic all along. So really no evolution or permanent change occurs." });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889459-623', { "TS": 1271889459, "Text": "I am unfamiliar with the cited paradox. However, in general, when people start trying to use mathematic<wbr></wbr>s to \"prove\" that something must exist simply because the odds in favor of it are astronomic<wbr></wbr>al then I get pretty skeptical. In this case, consider the bombardier beetle. It manufactur<wbr></wbr>es two chemicals within its body that explode on contact. It uses these chemicals to spray boiling hot liquid on anything that may attack it with spray nozzles that it can point in almost any direction. Why doesn\'t the beetle explode itself when these chemicals mix? Why doesn\'t the beetle get burned by the boiling hot liquid? Everything about the bombardier flies in the face of Darwin\'s hypothesis<wbr></wbr>. Every part of the bombardier beetle used in this deadly defense mechanism including its explosion proff mixing chamber and its heat resistant makeup HAD to come together all at once. Otherwise the beetle would have blown himself up the first time it mixed those chemicals. Not very likely to get itself very far along an \"evolution<wbr></wbr>ary\" path if it blows up every time a predator attacks. What do you suppose the odds of all those parts evolving at once are? One scientist who studies those beetles figured the odds were astronomic<wbr></wbr>al against it. He went from being a Darwinist to a creationis<wbr></wbr>t as his studies of the Bombardier continued. The Bible says that the evidence of the creator are within the things created. The house you build to live in is evidence of a builder. Things simply do not happen by themselves<wbr></wbr>. Otherwise we would be fond of saying things like \"Isn\'t it wonderful that that car just created itself out of nothing just in time for you to start using it?\"" });

JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889459-898', { "TS": 1271889459, "Text": "Actually Joe, I think I do understand it quite well. Your quote of \"theories can incorporat<wbr></wbr>e facts and laws and tested hypotheses<wbr></wbr>\" mentions only tested hypothesis<wbr></wbr>. Without at least one tested hypothesis you do not have a theory. Darwin\'s hypothesis attempts to extrapolat<wbr></wbr>e observatio<wbr></wbr>ns of the natural world as we see it today all the way back in time to the point where there was no life in a world that no one has ever seen much less left a record of. People have attempted and failed to recreate this so called primordial soup condition and attempted to coax life from lifelessne<wbr></wbr>ss using all kinds of external stimuli that were seen as plausible to exist. This is the basic brick in the hypothesis<wbr></wbr>, and until you can devise an experiment to show reliably and repeatedly by any research facility that life can be caused to occur from lifelessne<wbr></wbr>ss in some probable scenario, then all you have is a untested hypotheses<wbr></wbr>. Also, to counter your claim that gravity is a theory, I say that gravity is a natural condition that exists whether you understand it or not. If there was a valid theory of gravity then you should be able to manipulate it. Let us all know when you have come up with an anti-gravi<wbr></wbr>ty device. It will make you rich beyond the wildest dreams of avarice. By the way, I am a practicing Electronic<wbr></wbr>s Engineer so I have a pretty good grasp of things that would have been called \"magic\" only a couple of decades ago. The following link describes the scientific method. Among other things it supports my contention that a tested (proven true) hypothesis precedes an idea being advanced to the status of being a theory. http://www.sciencebuddies.org/science-fair-projects/project_scientific_method.shtml\n\n\n" });

ing+rate.++Hawking+radiation+may+be+pulling+our+universe+apart.++%0A%0AA+growing+singularity+within+a+super+massive+black+hole+seems+to+me+very+similar+to+the+description+of+the+first+moments+of+our+universe.++A+perfect+medium+of+infinite+mass.++Matter+stripped+down+to+it%E2%80%99s+most+basic+elements.++I+believe+these+are+one+and+the+same.+%0A%0AAt+the+instant+the+core+collapses+a+big+bang+occurs.++The+explosion+instantly+creates+a+bubble+within+the+mother+black+hole.++This+bubble+could+be+Guth%E2%80%99s+inflationary+theory.+++%0A%0ADark+matter+may+be+the+outer+regions+of+the+mother+black+hole+that+completely+surrounds+the+baby+universe.++A+shell+of+black+hole+would+have+a+powerful+gravitational+pull+of+its+own+pulling+the+baby+universe+apart.++The+baby+universe+grows+within+the+mother+black+hole+until+it+has+matured+and+eventually+dies.%0A%0ADark+energy+may+be+the+current+created+by+Hawking+radiation+leaking+back+into+the+mother+universe.++A+universe+dying+and+a+black+hole+evaporating+back+into+space+are+the+same+thing%2C+I+believe.+%0A&js-CmtEmail=parrymic%40comcast.net
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889484-545', { "TS": 1271889484, "Text": "Is it possible for a universe to be at the center of a black hole?\n\nA black hole is not a hole at all.  It’s relatively spherical.  A sphere that is 3,000 times the mass of our sun but only 10 times the diameter sits at the center of our Milky Way galaxy.  It powers the galaxy the way our sun powers our solar system, just on a much larger scale.  When I began to think of a Black Hole as a sphere and not some kind of drain that matter falls into, I started to see things differentl<wbr></wbr>y.  Matter was pulled into the center of a sphere, from all directions at once.  The singularit<wbr></wbr>y could be thought of as the core of the black hole.  \n\nI began to think of a black hole as a type of star.  What happens to a super massive star?  It’s life ends because gravity wins out.  The core collapses into a black hole.  Black holes grow by consuming gas and dust.  They also grow by  merging with other black holes.  It would make sense then to believe the core of the black hole would also grow.  What would happen to the black hole when and if gravity wins?  What would happen if the core of the black hole collapsed?  \n\nIs it possible that the energy released when the core of a black hole collapses ignites the birth of a new universe?  And that universe exists inside the mother black hole which itself exists in it’s own universe.  When the core collapses a big bang occurs.  A massive sun is destroyed after a supernova.  I believe a black hole survives its supernova.  The new universe will exist and expand from within the mother black hole.  I believe that energy from the baby universe radiates back into the mother universe by means of Hawking radiation.  Hawking radiation might even answer the question of the expanding universe.  Our universe is expanding at an ever increasing rate.  Hawking radiation may be pulling our universe apart.  \n\nA growing singularit<wbr></wbr>y within a super massive black hole seems to me very similar to the descriptio<wbr></wbr>n of the first moments of our universe.  A perfect medium of infinite mass.  Matter stripped down to it’s most basic elements.  I believe these are one and the same. \n\nAt the instant the core collapses a big bang occurs.  The explosion instantly creates a bubble within the mother black hole.  This bubble could be Guth’s inflationa<wbr></wbr>ry theory.   \n\nDark matter may be the outer regions of the mother black hole that completely surrounds the baby universe.  A shell of black hole would have a powerful gravitatio<wbr></wbr>nal pull of its own pulling the baby universe apart.  The baby universe grows within the mother black hole until it has matured and eventually dies.\n\nDark energy may be the current created by Hawking radiation leaking back into the mother universe.  A universe dying and a black hole evaporatin<wbr></wbr>g back into space are the same thing, I believe. \n" });

Supposing the Superheavy element is very stable and that we produce  1 nucleus by second ; we will require 2,32 x 10^13 days to produce that mg , or  63,6 billions years.\r\nSo in nature synergy of nuclear reactions are necessaril<wbr></wbr>y present\r\nhttp://albert.cau.free.fr/English/index.html" });

Or is it more likely our purpose is to achieve a complete understand<wbr></wbr>ing of how everything in the universe works?\r\n\r\nClearly I would choose the latter if I can. Once again, I would like to emphasize that, I chose that because I THINK we human being should trace our origin or we will just be the same as those wild animals and I don\'t want to be like that. This is only my choice. I am not saying that I am right. Of course we can also simply ignore those physical laws lying beyond our world and make a good living. But here comes the question which always annoys me. What is the meaning of surviving peacefully on this small planet? What is the meaning of such existence of ecosystem where we human beings exist? What is the meaning of continuing our species as long as we can though we will finally die when our Sun becomes a red giant which is expected to engulf our planet as expected by our knowledge of stars? When I think of these questions, I don\'t think making our living on this planet safely and peacefully has any meaning. That\'s why I chose the latter. (Though I admit that we NEED those people who care only our planet since without them, I probably can\'t live well.)\r\n\r\nIndeed, what do you mean by the simplest solution? Do you think that managing our planet is simpler than pursuiting the truth? Somebody may find it easier to deal with physics and mathematic<wbr></wbr>s than deal with people in the society. The planets have almost all the angular momentum and they are divided into distinct different groups. That does not happen by a slow congealing of a uniform gas evenly over time. JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889512-838', { "TS": 1271889512, "Text": "You are both right in that the Danish experiment<wbr></wbr>s were compared with Saturn\'s hexagon at the time, even though none of the critical dimensionl<wbr></wbr>ess parameters of this experiment matched those of Saturn itself even within an order of magnitude. That is what is different about our experiment - the Rossby number and basic instabilit<wbr></wbr>y mechanism in the experiment are plausible for conditions on Saturn, unlike the Danish experiment<wbr></wbr>s which merely reproduced polygonal patterns. We make no claim to be the first to produce polygons in fluids - there are plenty of examples in the literature already going back more than 20 years. What is different here is plausible dynamical similarity with Saturn (albeit only partial) - which we suggest is certainly not \'bad science\'!" });

Request sent: http://js-kit.com/comment.put?js-CmtName=Nasif+Nahle&js-CmtParentID=jsid-1271889544-611&js-CmtEmail=nns%40biocab.org&tid=jst-1&ref=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.sciencemag.org%2Fsciencenow%2F2010%2F04%2Fdoes-our-universe-live-inside-a-.html&js-CmtText=Expansion+of+the+space+within+what+references%3F+Essentially%2C+the+space+doesn%27t+expand%2C+although+systems+contained+by+a+given+space+can+expand.+If+a+given+space+is+contained+into+limiting+walls%2C+for+example+a+space+into+a+box%2C+it%E2%80%99s+the+walls+what+expand%3B+the+space+inside+those+walls+gets+larger+by+the+expansion+of+the+walls%2C+but+it+doesn%E2%80%99t+expand.+Nevertheless%2C+in+the+big+picture%2C+the+space+has+not+limits%2C+it%E2%80%99s+three-dimensional+and%2C+like+time%2C+the+space+is+infinite%2C+which+is+one+of+its+most+important+characteristics.
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889557-966', { "TS": 1271889558, "Text": "Expansion of the space within what references<wbr></wbr>? Essentiall<wbr></wbr>y, the space doesn\'t expand, although systems contained by a given space can expand. If a given space is contained into limiting walls, for example a space into a box, it’s the walls what expand; the space inside those walls gets larger by the expansion of the walls, but it doesn’t expand. Neverthele<wbr></wbr>ss, in the big picture, the space has not limits, it’s three-dime<wbr></wbr>nsional and, like time, the space is infinite, which is one of its most important characteri<wbr></wbr>stics." });

n+the+Palella+study+were+healthy+before+starting+antiretrovirals.+This+is+not+the+case%2C+all+had+%3C100+CD4+T+cells+and+many+had+previous+opportunistic+infections.+Duesberg+et+al+have+altered+the+quote+from+the+Palella+paper+to+make+it+seem+like+people+with+opportunistic+infections+were+excluded.+But+this+is+what+the+quote+says+in+the+actual+paper%3A%0A%0A%22Patients+with+a+diagnosis+of+cytomegalovirus+retinitis+or+M.+avium+complex+disease+before+study+entry+or+during+the+first+30+days+of+follow-up+and+patients+with+active+P.+carinii+pneumonia+at+the+beginning+of+follow-up+were+excluded+from+the+analyses+of+the+incidence+of+that+opportunistic+infection.%22%0A%0AIn+other+words%2C+they+weren%27t+excluded+from+the+study%2C+they+just+weren%27t+counted+as+having+developed+that+particular+opportunistic+infection+during+the+study%2C+if+it+was+pre-existing+or+developed+during+he+first+30+days.+Because+the+sentence%2C+in+its+original+form%2C+is+also+an+acknowledgement+that+people+entered+the+study+with+a+history+of+opportunistic+infections+and+not+just+low+CD4+counts+-+i.e.+not+%22asymptomatic%22+or+%22AIDS+free%22+as+Duesberg+is+claiming+-+Duesberg+accomplishes+a+double+deception+just+by+inserting+a+period+after+the+word+%22excluded.%22+%0A%0AThe+fact+that+the+Palella+paper+reports+data+on+people+who+never+took+antiretrovirals+also+contradicts+Duesberg%27s+statement+that+%22Neither+of+these+studies+mentions+drug-free+controls.%22%0A%0AThe+late+Martin+Delaney+of+Project+Inform+also+wrote+a+letter+to+the+NAS+many+years+ago+demanding+that+they+review+Duesberg%27s+membership%3B+as+far+as+I+know+he+never+received+a+response.+I%27ll+post+a+copy+if+I+can+find+it.+&js-CmtEmail=richard.jefferys%40treatmentactiongroup.org
Response
JSReplyMSGId('jst-1', 'jsid-1271889564-59', { "TS": 1271889564, "Text": "It\'s about time. Here\'s an example of Duesberg (along with co-authors Claus Koehnlein and David Rasnick) deliberate<wbr></wbr>ly misquoting an NEJM paper in an article they published in 2003:\n\nhttp://www.duesberg.com/papers/chemical-bases.html\n\n\"the evidence for \'declining morbidity and mortality\' is only based on uncontroll<wbr></wbr>ed survey studies that investigat<wbr></wbr>ed how long HIV-positi<wbr></wbr>ve, clinically healthy subjects, but mostly from AIDS risk groups, survived on various anti-HIV drugs. The largest and most influentia<wbr></wbr>l of these surveys was conducted by Palella et al (1998) who investigat<wbr></wbr>ed in 1998 1255 anti-HIV drug-treat<wbr></wbr>ed \'patients, each of which had at least one CD4+ count below 100\' from nine clinics in the US. However, all of these \'patients\' were \'nonhospit<wbr></wbr>alized\', AIDS-free subjects. \'Patients with a diagnosis of cytomegalo<wbr></wbr>virus retinitis or M. aviarum complex disease before study entry or during the first 30 days of follow-up and patients with active P. carinii pneumonia at the beginning of follow-up were excluded.\' A similar survey investigat<wbr></wbr>ed in 2001 1219 anti-HIV drug-treat<wbr></wbr>ed Canadian HIV-positi<wbr></wbr>ves with less than 200 CD4+ cells, of which 87% were AIDS-free (Hogg et al 2001). Neither of these studies mentions drug-free controls.\"\n\nThe NEJM paper by Frank Pallela that is being misquoted focused on people with advanced illness (less than 100 CD4 T cells). The full text is available online: http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/338/13/853\n\nThe data shows the highest mortality was among people that never took antiretrov<wbr></wbr>irals, the lowest among people on triple combinatio<wbr></wbr>ns (see table 1). \n\nWhat Duesberg does to try and explain away the data is pretend that the participan<wbr></wbr>ts in the Palella study were healthy before starting antiretrov<wbr></wbr>irals. This is not the case, all had &lt;100 CD4 T cells and many had previous opportunis<wbr></wbr>tic infections<wbr></wbr>. Duesberg et al have altered the quote from the Palella paper to make it seem like people with opportunis<wbr></wbr>tic infections were excluded. But this is what the quote says in the actual paper:\n\n\"Patients with a diagnosis of cytomegalo<wbr></wbr>virus retinitis or M. avium complex disease before study entry or during the first 30 days of follow-up and patients with active P. carinii pneumonia at the beginning of follow-up were excluded from the analyses of the incidence of that opportunis<wbr></wbr>tic infection.<wbr></wbr>\"\n\nIn other words, they weren\'t excluded from the study, they just weren\'t counted as having developed that particular opportunis<wbr></wbr>tic infection during the study, if it was pre-existi<wbr></wbr>ng or developed during he first 30 days. Because the sentence, in its original form, is also an acknowledg<wbr></wbr>ement that people entered the study with a history of opportunis<wbr></wbr>tic infections and not just low CD4 counts - i.e. not \"asymptoma<wbr></wbr>tic\" or \"AIDS free\" as Duesberg is claiming - Duesberg accomplish<wbr></wbr>es a double deception just by inserting a period after the word \"excluded.<wbr></wbr>\" \n\nThe fact that the Palella paper reports data on people who never took antiretrov<wbr></wbr>irals also contradict<wbr></wbr>s Duesberg\'s statement that \"Neither of these studies mentions drug-free controls.\"\n\nThe late Martin Delaney of Project Inform also wrote a letter to the NAS many years ago demanding that they review Duesberg\'s membership<wbr></wbr>; as far as I know he never received a response. I\'ll post a copy if I can find it. " });
